A young man is diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome. What are his chances ofr having healthy children without medical assistance?
Correct Answer: In most cases, men with Klinefelter syndrome are infertile
Possible Answer 1: Men with Klinefelter syndrome are fertile.  They do not have a significant increased risk of having abnormal offspring.
Possible Answer 2: In most cases, men with Klinefelter syndrome are infertile
Possible Answer 3: Men with Klinefelter syndrome are fertile, but they have a significantly increased risk of having abnormal offspring
Possible Answer 4: In rare cases, men with Klinefelter syndrome are infertile. When they do have kids, their children will most likely carry translocations.

Question: George and Daisy have two sons with Down's syndrome. George's brother Henry has Down's sydrome. His sister Beth has a daughter with Down's syndrome. Which of the following statements is most likely to be correct?
Possible Answer 1: George and Daisy's sons both have 47 chromosomes

Question: A woman experiences a spontaneous abortion. The aborted fetus has the karyotype 47,XY,+8. An investigation of a polymorphic DNA marker on chromosome 8 showed that the fetus and parents had the following alleles: Mother: allele 2 and 6, Father: allele 3 and 5, Fetus: allele 3 and 6. The trisomy can be explained by non-disjunction in meiosis. Which parent and in what meiotic division did this non-disjunction take place?
Correct Answer: Only in the second meiotic division in either the mother or the father
Possible Answer 1: Only in the second meiotic division in either the mother or the father
Possible Answer 2: Only in the mother in her first or second meiotic division
Possible Answer 3: Only in the mother, and only in her second meiotic division
Possible Answer 4: Only in the father in his first or second meiotic division

Question: Which of the following karyotypes are most likely to be found in a three month old child of a parent who carries a balanced Robertsonian translocation 45,XX,der(14;21)(q10;q10)?

Individuals with three copies of autosomal chromosomes normally do not survive (except trisomies of e.g. 13, 18 and 21), whereas individuals with an extra X chromosome have relatively mild phenotypes. Why?
Correct Answer: The extra X chromosomes will be inactivated
Possible Answer 1: The X chromosome carries fewer genes than the autosomes
Possible Answer 2: The X chromosome only determines the sex of the individual
Possible Answer 3: All of the autosomes are acrocentric
Possible Answer 4: The extra X chromosomes will be inactivated

Question: A woman has Turner syndrome and X-linked recessive colorblindness. Her father has normal vision and her uncle (mother's brother) is colorblind. A non-disjunction event occured that led to her chromosomal aberration. When and where did it take place?
Correct Answer: On her father's first or second meiotic division
Possible Answer 1: On her mother's first or second meiotic division
Possible Answer 2: On her father's first or second meiotic division
Possible Answer 3: On her mother's first or father's first meiotic division
Possible Answer 4: Only on her father's second meiotic division

Question: Can a person with Turners syndrome become pregnant and give birth to a child? Select the most correct statement.
Correct Answer: In very rare cases, she can become pregnant and give birth
Possible Answer 1: In very rare cases, she can become pregnant and give birth
Possible Answer 2: Yes, she can become pregnant and give birth
Possible Answer 3: It is most likely that she can become pregnant and give birth
Possible Answer 4: She can become pregnant and give birth, but all of the children will have serious chromosomal abnormalities

Question: Karyotype analysis of an infertile man reveals 46,XX. How can such a karyotype originate?
Correct Answer: By translocation of a part of the Y chromosome on to one of the X chromsomes
Possible Answer 1: By duplication of the Y chromosome, so that it can no longer be recognized
Possible Answer 2: By non-disjunction of the Y chromosome during the second meiotic division
Possible Answer 3: By translocation of a part of the Y chromosome on to one of the X chromsomes
Possible Answer 4: By deletion of the centromere region of the Y chromosome, which leads to loss of the Y

Question: The figure shows the results of a fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis. Which probes were used and what does the analysis reveal?
Correct Answer: It used paint probes (spectral karyotyping) recognizing chromosome 2 and 13 to reveal a reciprocal translocation between these two chromosomes
Possible Answer 1: It used probes recognizing the centromere regions of chromosome 2 and 13 revealing a Robertsonian translocation between these two chromosomes
Possible Answer 2: It used probes recognizing two frequent sequences in the genome showing the localization of these sequences in a normal man
Possible Answer 3: It used paint probes (spectral karyotyping) recognizing chromosome 2 and 13 revealing an inversion on each of these two chromosomes
Possible Answer 4: It used paint probes (spectral karyotyping) recognizing chromosome 2 and 13 to reveal a reciprocal translocation between these two chromosomes

Question: A healthy man carries a balanced reciprocal translocation which can be described by: 46,XY,t(1;18)(p22;q23). What does this karyotype mean for his chances of getting normal and healthy children?
Correct Answer: He can have healthy children, if he passes on the normal chromosomes 1 and 18, or if he passes on the two derivative chromosomes so that the child becomes a carrier of the same balanced translocation
Possible Answer 1: He can not have healthy children, as he will always passes on one or both of the two derivative chromosomes so that the child becomes a carrier of an unbalanced translocation
Possible Answer 2: He can in very rare cases have healthy children, but only if he passes on the normal chromosomes 1 and 18
Possible Answer 3: He will only have healthy children since his translocation is balanced
Possible Answer 4: He can have healthy children, if he passes on the normal chromosomes 1 and 18, or if he passes on the two derivative chromosomes so that the child becomes a carrier of the same balanced translocation

Question: Which one of the following karyotypes do you NOT expect to find in a patient with Down's syndrome?
If an infertile man has one Barr body in his cell nuclei, which of the following is most likely to be his karyotype?
When preparing the chromosomes for karyotyping, why do we add colcemid (or colchicine) to the cells?
Correct Answer: To stop the cell division in metaphase where the chromosomes are most condensed
Possible Answer 1: To stop the cell division and reduce the number of cells in the final sample
Possible Answer 2: To stimulate the cells to divide
Possible Answer 3: To stop the cell division in metaphase where the chromosomes are most condensed
Possible Answer 4: To label the chromosomes for visualization

Question: What chromosomal rearrangement must have taken place in order to change the chromosome on the left into the derivative chromosome on the right?
The person with the above karyotype has no symptoms of any genetic disease, but what is the risk for his children to have consequences due to the translocation he carries?
Correct Answer: There is a risk for him to have children with Down's syndrome or miscarriages as well as possibility to have normal children
Possible Answer 2: There is no risk of chromosome abnormalities for his children due to his translocation
Possible Answer 3: All his children will have Down's syndrome
Possible Answer 4: There is a risk for him to have children with Down's syndrome or miscarriages as well as possibility to have normal children

Question: A child is born with the karyotype 47,XXX. This can be caused by non-disjunction, but what can we determine about in who and at which meiotic division?
Correct Answer: It can be in the mother, her first or second meiotic division, or in the second meiotic division in the father
Possible Answer 1: It has to be in the mother, her first or second meiotic division
Possible Answer 2: It can be in the mother, her first or second meiotic division, or in the second meiotic division in the father
Possible Answer 3: It can only be in the father, his first meiotic division
Possible Answer 4: It can only be in the second meiotic division, in either the mother or the father

Question: A phenotypically normal boy has 45 chromosomes. His sister, who has Downs syndrome, has 46 chromosomes. Why?
Correct Answer: Both children have a Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21. His is balanced, while hers is unbalanced with an extra chromosome 21
Possible Answer 1: The sister has a balanced Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21
Possible Answer 2: The boy only has one sex chromosome, while the sister has two
Possible Answer 3: The boy has an unbalanced Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21
Possible Answer 4: Both children have a Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21. His is balanced, while hers is unbalanced with an extra chromosome 21

Question: A young couple has for two years tried to have children without success. The wife has experienced several miscarriages. Their karyotypes are 46,XX and 45,XY,der(22;22)(q10;q10). What different phenotypes can we expect in their future children?
Correct Answer: We expect that the couple is infertile, experiencing numerous miscarriages due to abnormal karyotypes
Possible Answer 1: We expect all children to have the same balanced translocation as the father, and hence be normal
Possible Answer 2: We expect that they will have children with the same balanced translocation as the father and normal phenotype; all other possible karyotypes will lead to miscarriage
Possible Answer 3: We expect that the couple is infertile, experiencing numerous miscarriages due to abnormal karyotypes
Possible Answer 4: We expect a high risk of children with Down's syndrome, and a high frequency of micarriages

Question: Array CGH analysis of a young child with developmental abnormalities revealed that the short arm of chromosome 4 was present in only one copy. What does this mean?
Correct Answer: The child most likely suffers from Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome due to a deletion on 4p
Possible Answer 1: The child most likely suffers from Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome due to a deletion on 4p
Possible Answer 2: The child suffers from Turner syndrome due to a deletion on 4q
Possible Answer 3: The child most likely suffers from Cri du Chat syndrome
Possible Answer 4: The child has Edwards syndrome due to a duplication on 4p

Question: A person with the karyotype 46,XX,der(18)t(12;18)(p13;q12) carries 46 chromosomes. A part of the short arm of chromosome 12 has replaced a part of the long arm of chromosome 18 in one of the chromosome 18 pair (the derivative chromosome 18) due to a translocation, inherited from her father. What does this mean?
Correct Answer: She has three copies of the short arm of chromosome 12
Possible Answer 1: She has only one coyp of the short arm of chromosome 18
Possible Answer 2: She has three copies of the long arm of chromosome 18
Possible Answer 3: She has three copies of the short arm of chromosome 12
Possible Answer 4: She has only one copy of the long arm of chromosome 12
